name: The Unholy Fist's Redemption - Monk 35 / Blackguard 4 / Paladin 1
author: DoesntPlayAnymore

posts.author: DoesntPlayAnymore
posts.content:
This is my first post on this forum, so - hello! I have been lurking for many years and learnt so much from all you guys. I don't play much anymore, but I am somewhere on the spectrum and the CBC sheet is probably the best game I have ever played!

Anyway, here is a build I have been tinkering with. I first got inspired by EasternPromise's funtastic Lawful Sexy, a Master Roshi tale: Monk 25 / Paladin 3 / Champion of Torm 10, where he combines Monk with Paladin for Divine Might and Grace. That got me wanting to do my own unarmed Monk with Divine feats.

I then saw Orion2019's post, Fallen Paladin with 10 attacks (ie Paladin 12 / Monk 2-6 / Blackguard 22-26) - concept only, where he combines Paladin and Blackguard for fantastic saves together with a few levels of Monk. I could only find one build in the archives, Blood Knight monk 9 / paladin 15 / blackguard 16 by TyrTemplar. Both of these builds use Monk as a minor class and don't focus on fists so no good for what I am looking for.

I remembered Valerfor's THE IRON FIST (MONK 35/ FTR 5), a build that goes for spectacular spell resistance and EWS. I think my build resembles this the most. I added Divine Might instead of EWS (can be buffed to potentially higher damage) and one more SR feat. Instead of CoT levels for the Wisdom dump as in Lawful Sexy, my toon gets AC from Divine Shield, and is arguably even better against spells due to 51(!) SR. Furthermore, the saves from CoT count towards the dodge cap, and the Divine Wratch AB towards AB cap. Without having done the math, I think both builds will have similar saves in high magic environments due to double saves bonus from Pal/BG.

Anyway, here is my first build!

Remaining skill points can be whatever you like. I chose Spellcraft and Listen.

PRO's:
- Fantastic SR
- Decent damage unbuffed becomes great with buffs + equipment
- Acceptable AC with magic stuff
- Good saves great with magic stuff
- Maxed Taunt

CON'S:
- No magic stuff - no very good.
- No UMD
- No Uncanny Dodge to protect dodge AC 
- Alignment change - there is 25 levels for this which I think is acceptable.

Final notes: For some reason, I thought my first build here would/should be some convoluted mess, but I am pleased by how simple this guy turned out to be. The leveling order can be changed a bit to have Paladin first to access double saves boost sooner, but I think the Fallen Paladin trope is becoming a cliché and personally I prefer the Hero's Redemption story arc much more and having the Paladin level very last makes the whole thing seem more believable. Also, taking Paladin at 15 and BG at 40 cost's two alignment changes (and probably your soul.)

For different splits Pal 1/BG 3 will max SR, but then no maxed taunt and Sneak Attack. Pal 3/BG 2 gives DS and DM and a not good Smite Evil, no Sneak. Less Monk gives less SR, and I like the SR. Could also go uber cheese with a Spellcraft/UMD dump class.

Starting charisma can be lowered to have slightly better unbuffed HP and Fort or Ref or Will or Skills, but that defeats the purpose of the Divine Feats.

Please rip this guy apart!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Welcome to the guild, (even if you) "DoesntPlayAnymore".

I agree with you - the CBC sheet is a great game.

As for the build: kudos for originality.
A charismatic main class monk is not something you see every day and reversing the "fallen paladin" is an interesting twist to the double saves bonus theme.
A strength monk benefits from dexterity, wisdom and constitution for AC, hitpoints, saves, stunning fist and quivering palm. You also want enough intelligence to get the skills you want, so charisma often becomes the ability to dump.
So the challenge with a build like this is to avoid that the abilities you want are stretched too thin.
The AB of your build looks good. The naked AC may seem a little low. It will help with both dex and wis gear/potions, and you get +9 to dodge AC from DS with a maxed out charisma. This kind of gear will also improve your already very good saves.
The SR is good, but not water proof (for that you need an SR of 67 or better). Yet it will annoy any unprepared mage. A pure level 40 mage without penetration feats will have to roll a 1d20 + 40 to try and beat the SR. He will succeed with a roll of 11 or better, meaning 50% of the time. But with most spells he also has to overcome your saves that are very good.
In the unlikely case that said level 40 mage also has epic spell penetration, the roll to beat SR is 1d20 + 46. Now he will succeed with a roll of 5 or better, meaning 80% of the time, but he still has to beat your saving throw with most of his spells.

posts.author: DoesntPlayAnymore
posts.content:
@Mick Dagger  OK, I think I've got it... Closer! Since charisma isn't a combat stat before level 11 and not really before level 12 and DM I decided to lower it to 15 and increase it at level 12. I also took 2 points from CON and voila, 14 WIS. I think the loss of HP is worth the +2 to AC, having better Stunning Fist DC and the better Will save before Monk 20 but does put him into Glass Cannon territory. 

I changed the last bonus monk feat from SR to armor skin and used the last general feat to get STR 30, figuring 49 SR is still in the ballpark of 50/50 against pure casters without SP feats and very, very annoying against level 26's with those. Pure casters with penetration (who does that?) instead have to worry a little more because of the more menacing DC 32 stunning fists.

Here is a similar build in spirit, his evil rapscallion nemesis and twin broter who uncannily and epically dodges responsibility and does improved tax evasion (I wish I could fit in "Crippling Debt" as well)... He never learnt his ways. 
At the end of the movie level 40 they meet, and Bad Brother will try to get help with some gambling debt or rent reminding Good Brother of "the good old days" in the Karate club where they bullied and hustled less skilled kids. But Good Brother "has a family now" and "has changed" and is "too old for this shi-" (scene cut.) Commence 10 minutes of powering up to "not even final form" divine mights,  taunts, stunning fists and knockdown spam on top of a skyscraper in Toronto (because budget.)

The build is a bit more interesting both on paper and in playstyle, getting access to UMD 35 and ED at 30. Divine and Bludgeoning damage might also be more interesting for a DEX sneaker to deal with pesky sneak immunes, especially Undead. AC is much much better, but damage, SR and saves (buffed) are lower. Can't have everything. Criticism of course very welcome. I still need to properly test both builds with the updated stats.

Ok, I think I'm getting even closer. I changed the split to M 20 / BG 19 / P 1. This gets the most important monk feats, and three (good) BG epic bonus feats (assuming no Devastating Crit.) It loses the good SR and super speed in exchange for much better charisma, keeps the AB at 40 and also gets 6d6 sneak attacks. There is a 5 level grace period to git gud (lawful good) which should still be playable/RP-able. The higher charisma works well with the gimmick to get better saves, longer and better DM/DS and better a better taunt.
